Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: I'm curious about the Turing completeness of Komodo smart contract, will it be Turing-completed ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I dont design things to meet abstract litmus tests, like "turing complete" (which i think actually requires infinite storage which no practical system can have). Rather, I design to solve the actual things that need to be solved. So describe a specific useful smart contract and I can tell you if it will be supported

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: from wikipedia: To show that something is Turing complete, it is enough to show that it can be used to simulate some Turing complete system. For example, an imperative language is Turing complete if it has conditional branching (e.g., "if" and "goto" statements, or a "branch if zero" instruction; see one instruction set computer) and the ability to change an arbitrary amount of memory (e.g., the ability to maintain an arbitrary number of data items). Of course, no physical system can have infinite memory; but if the limitation of finite memory is ignored, most programming languages are otherwise Turing complete.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so an incomplete turing completeness litmus test?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I ask why is that important

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us make a list of specific smart contracts and then just make sure all of them are supported, ie be able to change parameters and other practical customizations that real world usages will want to do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: atomic swaps are a smart contract, it does the job it is supposed to do, yet it isnt turing complete, even the incomplete definition. So does that make atomic swaps not useful?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: If the problem at hand is solved, I claim that the problem at hand is solved, regardless of its turing completeness

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: Also, notice that if we dont have to make a turing complete contracts, we can avoid a massive amount of security  issues  not to mention the effort required to make it turing complete. So why build something that will certainly create security issues if it isnt needed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I like to iterate from the simplest possible solution and if that isnt sufficient to add a bit more. I stop when the problem is solved. I expect we wont have to go to full turing completeness (with finite mem) in order to be able to run 99% of the useful smart contracts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I think the logic used is that "a turing complete contracts system can solve any smart contract, so if we had a turing complete system we are golden"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this misses the very real risks satoshi designed the bitcoin script system to avoid and then then disabled most of those opcodes!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but the turing question is a misdirection!! The better question is "can the smart contract system solve the problem it needs to solve without creating giant security attack vectors and unknowns"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: So while a turing complete system would be able to say it can implement any contract, it isnt without a giant caveat, ie. any contract includes a lot of contracts with undesirable behavior.

Author: vasa#4326
Content: I have a question about dPoS.

Author: vasa#4326
Content: The dPoS Wiki says that: Within this scheme, each notary is allowed to mine one block at its current difficulty rate, while the other notary nodes must mine at 10 time higher and all the normal nodes will always mine at 100 times the difficulty rate of the notary nodes.

Author: vasa#4326
Content: What is the reason behind putting high difficulty to the other nodes than the mining node?

Author: vasa#4326
Content: I couldn't figure out the problem it is solving...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW not dPoW, this text appears to be confused.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notaries get to mine at easy diff once per 65 blocks

Author: vasa#4326
Content: Yeah..sorry about that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: other than that the diff works normally

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no matter how high the hashrate goes, the notaries will get about 75% of the blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this allows notaries to know they will get revenues coming in

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also it is ASIC resistant

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also it makes it that much harder to get 51% the hashrate as many of the notaries would have to be compromised

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it solves the problem of paying for notary nodes, securing the chain, resisting ASIC

Author: vasa#4326
Content: That's great...the thing that :the notaries will get about 75% of the blocks

Author: vasa#4326
Content: Is this some rule in the consensus?

Author: vasa#4326
Content: Or it is derived from the difficulty other nodes are facing?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we tune the notary mining to achieve the 25%

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the lower the external miner percentage gets, the slower the notaries take to mine

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the real hashrate has no effect on notaries, they can always mine one in 65 blocks, whether external miners are 10MH, 10GH or 10TH or even 10PH

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but we need to calibrate it to reality, or the diff can explode. in our early days on testnet the diff did explode up into the billions, so we added the free for all mining, once per 2000 blocks where notaries are not able to mine at easy diff, but they still notarize during this time. This resets the diff to the actal hashrate

Author: vasa#4326
Content: According to above: 25 % for the non notary miners. right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: approx

Author: vasa#4326
Content:
And I read it in your google docs: Our latest stress test had 1024 chains, and we achieved 20k transactions per second (TPS).

On Komodo, we can include multiple payments on a single transaction, so thus we can also say we made over 800k payments per second.

Content: not sure if there were any errors during the txblasting, it is just a simulation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
not sure if you know, but komodod has the insight-core support built into it now. there are many -addressindex rpc calls also a -spentindex to allow an explorer like insight explorer to just call the coin daemon

then there is the electrumX server that does mostly the same thing to implement api: https://electrumx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/protocol-methods.html

What I am thinking is that it could be a very small layer that publishes the electrum api and then calls the komodod -addressindex=1 -spentindex=1 daemon and for things that dont exist right away (like generating spv proofs, we actually have that code from the MoMoM work)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is a nice self-contained project that can be done in any language and looking for someone to do this

Author: vasa#4326
Content: cool. I will look into it.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
== Addressindex ==
getaddressbalance
getaddressdeltas
getaddressmempool
getaddresstxids
getaddressutxos
getspentinfo
gettxoutproof ["txid",...] ( blockhash )

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: those komodod rpc calls should make it relatively easy to implement electrum API

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe even add a -SPV=port option to make a komodod run an electrum server

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: what percentage of blocks on the mainchain should notaries be producing?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @ComputerGenie I don't understand your comment entirely. The BadMinerA can reject the GoodMiner blocks and outpace them. This way, if they dont comply with his censor list, they wont get their blocks mined

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: im talking with jl about this, maybe he'll answer my questions

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: this is how soft forks generally work, the miners that are in the minority in the soft fork fall behind and stop being able to mine blocks

Author: Alright#0419
Content: GoodMiner's blocks would still be accepted by notaries

Author: Alright#0419
Content: and once notarized, they are the real chain

Author: Alright#0419
Content: BadMiner could do it between notarizations, but it's impossible to predict when a notarization will happen

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content:
Okay, so imagine this attack on an asset chain notarizing every 20 blocks:
 - Bad Miner has 65% of asset chain hashrate
 - We are at block 100 (it has been notarized)
 - Bad Miner starts mining block 101. He is mining privately so he doesn't publish when he finds a block.
 - Good miners (35%) start mining 101
 - This creates competing private and public chains
 - Bad miner only publishes his chain every 20 blocks so that his chain keeps getting notarized.
- I don't the maths off the top of my head but as you exceed 50% hashrate your chance of being the first to 20 block becomes exponentially greater
 - As miners stop getting rewards they will leave, furthering your hold on the assetchain

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Badminer can't predict when the public chain will be notarized
